instruction: [INST] Analyze this file to learn MacBook motherboard repair. The 'definitions' section explains key technical terms. The 'threads' section contains real-world repair discussions. Use both sections to understand and learn how to troubleshoot MacBook issues. Posts from username 'larossmann' , 'dukefawks' , and '2informaticos' are posts from trusted experts.[/INST]

definitions.A2338: What is A2338? A2338 is a model number for a 13 inch size MacBook Pro Retina from years Late 2020 M1, Mid 2022 M2 with EMC 8162, that may contain one of these boards depending on the year & configuration: 820-02020, 820-02773..
definitions.820-02020: What is 820-02020? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.
definitions.PP3V3_S2: What is PP3V3_S2? PP3V3_S2 is a typo of PP3V3_S3.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-02020</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A2338</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> 2020 MacBook Pro problem with <SIGNAL>PP3V3_S2</SIGNAL>
threads.message:
This is the first M1 board I have worked on, so still learning the new nomenclature. Its USB-C is at 20V, drawing 0.02A. I found a short to ground on <SIGNAL>PP3V3_S2</SIGNAL>, which I traced to its power chip UC710 and open current sense resistor RD560. I replaced UC710 and RD560, which removed the short. Now I have:

<SIGNAL>PPBUS_AON</SIGNAL>: 12.0V
<SIGNAL>PP3V3_AON</SIGNAL>: 3.3V
<SIGNAL>PP1V8_AON</SIGNAL>: 1.8V
<SIGNAL>PP3V8_AON</SIGNAL>: 3.8V
<SIGNAL>PP3V3_S2</SIGNAL>: 2.8V
<SIGNAL>P3V3S2_EN</SIGNAL>: 1.8V

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-02020</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A2338</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> 2020 MacBook Pro problem with <SIGNAL>PP3V3_S2</SIGNAL>
threads.message: Check resistors RC709-14 and their traces.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-02020</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A2338</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> 2020 MacBook Pro problem with <SIGNAL>PP3V3_S2</SIGNAL>
threads.message: Those resistors are looking good. Is 1.8V for an enable signal normal on these boards?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-02020</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A2338</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> 2020 MacBook Pro problem with <SIGNAL>PP3V3_S2</SIGNAL>
threads.message:
Looking good and checked good is not the same.
RC709-13 set the <SIGNAL>3V3_S2</SIGNAL> voltage.
Check what happens soldering 150K in parallel with RC713.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-02020</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A2338</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> 2020 MacBook Pro problem with <SIGNAL>PP3V3_S2</SIGNAL>
threads.message:
By "looking good" I meant I measured all resistors. You were right about checking their traces, though. I reflowed the area because of one small corrosion spot and now I get 3.5V on <SIGNAL>PP3V3_S2</SIGNAL>.

The machine is starting up now.
